title: What They’re Reading: Book Picks From Business Leaders
text:
Text size

From a single-volume history of the U.S. to books dealing with personal and organizational growth, here’s what business leaders are reading.

Brian Armstrong,

CEO and co-founder, Coinbase

The Advantage: Why Organizational Health Trumps Everything Else In Business, by Patrick Lencioni

“The Advantage gives great insight into building and running a healthy organization. The better the health of the organization, the greater its potential to succeed.”

Penny Pennington,

Managing partner, Edward Jones

Alive at Work: The Neuroscience of Helping Your People Love What They Do, by Daniel Cable

“Alive at Work was recommended to me by Tim Welsh, vice chair of U.S. Bank. It’s all about creating an environment in our organizations where every professional can connect their own personal ‘why’ to the mission of the organization. One of the compelling points Cable makes is that human beings are wired to be ‘seekers.’ We get meaning in our work when we are able to use our natural curiosity to seek better ideas and solutions.”

Stephanie Chung,

President, JetSuite

Conversational Intelligence: How Great Leaders Build Trust and Get Extraordinary Results, by Judith E. Glaser

“This book, written by my mentor, who passed away last year, is one that I dust off and reread a few times every year. It’s about the power of the conversation and how the brain reacts—good or bad—to the way information is delivered. The brain controls all of our thoughts, emotions, and behaviors, yet we hardly acknowledge how it shows up in a conversation.”

David Frame, CEO, J.P. Morgan

U.S. Wealth Management

Range: Why Generalists Triumph in a Specialized World, by David Epstein

“Much has been written about the power of being a specialist, and committing to a specialty both early in life and in a career. This ranges from sports at a young age to anxiety around switching careers later in life. Range takes on this broad set of assumptions and makes the case for how building a wide range of skills can help you succeed at any age.”

Lucas Zwirner,

Head of content, David Zwirner

Attention: Dispatches from a Land of Distraction, by Joshua Cohen

These Truths: A History of the United States, by Jill Lepore

“Right now, I’m particularly drawn to books that help me understand the times we’re in. The novelist Joshua Cohen’s recent collection of essays, Attention: Dispatches from a Land of Distraction, deals with basically every aspect of modern life—from the literary to the banal, corrupt, and absurd.

Jill Lepore’s These Truths: A History of the United States is probably the best single-volume history of the United States now in existence. It puts the horrors of slavery front and center, and it should be on everyone’s reading list.”
